ground_truth: The attendant holds out a towel, and Don wipes his hands. He looks at Don’s lapel, mystified. Don tips the attendant with a fifty-cent piece. The attendant doesn’t get the joke but chuckles automatically and opens the door into the bar. Don walks from the washroom, slowly toward his table. Suddenly he stops and looks around. They are staring at Don. Near the little piano stand Don’s waiter, the head waiter, the piano player, and the lovers. In fact, he’s suddenly aware that he is the focus of every eye in the room. M. M.'s escort is right at him, grabbing him by the coat. He takes the bag out from under his coat and hands it to the lady. M. M.'s escort snatches it from his hand. Don holds out the bill and fishes what money he has left from his pocket. The waiter snaps it up. By this time, they’ve got Don to the door. The headwaiter gets Don’s hat from the checkroom girl’s hand, puts it on Don’s head, and the bouncer pulls him through the door. The bouncer, dragging Don from Harry's and Joe's, gives him one last shove down the street. Don comes to a stop and leans heavily against an iron railing, wiping his face with his hand. He straightens his hat, looks back. The doorman and the taxi drivers are staring after him. Don turns, straightens himself as best he can, and starts for home, shame weighing down every limb. There is a line of waiting taxis along the brilliantly lighted nightclub street. It is meanly lighted by the wall brackets. The newspaper, the bottle of milk, and Helen’s note are all as they were. Don drags himself up the last few steps, unlocks the door, and goes in, leaving the paper, bottle, and note untouched. Don has entered. Automatically he switches on the light in the corridor. In a stupor of shame and misery, he stumbles over to the living room couch, flings himself down on it, and lies covering his face with his arms. After a time, he brushes the tears from his eyes with his sleeve and, as he does so, catches sight of something which rivets his attention and brings a half-crazed smile to his lips. On the ceiling is the shadow of the bottle which he hid in the light fixture. With new strength, Don gets to his feet, nervous laughter shaking him. He pulls the coffee table under the light fixture, puts the chair on it, climbs up, and retrieves his bottle. He climbs down again, opening the bottle fiercely. Don opens his eyes slowly. Don gets up, steadying himself on the bedpost and holding the door frame, he slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Synonym Substitution

The attendant doesn’t understand the joke but laughs involuntarily and opens the door into the bar. Don strolls from the lavatory, gradually toward his table. Suddenly he pauses and glances around. The server snaps it up. By this point, they’ve led Don to the entrance. The headwaiter obtains Don’s hat from the checkroom girl’s hand, places it on Don’s head, and the bouncer pulls him through the door. He adjusts his hat, looks back. The doorman and the taxi drivers are gazing after him. Don turns, straightens himself as best he can, and begins for home, shame weighing down every limb. There is a line of waiting taxis along the brilliantly illuminated nightclub street. It is dimly lighted by the wall brackets. The newspaper, the bottle of milk, and Helen’s note are all as they were. Don drags himself up the last few steps, unlocks the door, and enters, leaving the paper, bottle, and note untouched. Don has entered. Automatically he activates the light in the corridor. In a stupor of shame and misery, he stumbles over to the living room couch, flings himself down on it, and lies covering his face with his arms. After a time, he wipes the tears from his eyes with his sleeve and, as he does so, catches sight of something which rivets his attention and brings a half-crazed smile to his lips. On the ceiling is the shadow of the bottle which he hid in the light fixture. With new vigor, Don rises to his feet, nervous laughter shaking him. He pulls the coffee table under the light fixture, places the chair on it, climbs up, and retrieves his bottle. He descends again, opening the bottle fiercely. Don opens his eyes slowly. Don rises, steadying himself on the bedpost and holding the door frame, he slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L1
test_cases.description: The attendant hands Don a towel, and Don wipes his hands. Eyeing Don’s lapel, puzzled, the attendant takes a fifty-cent tip, chuckles reflexively, and opens the bar door. Don exits the washroom and walks toward his table but halts—everyone is staring. By the piano stand are his waiter, the head waiter, the piano player, and the lovers. M. M.'s escort grabs Don’s coat, and Don hands over the bag. The escort snatches it, and Don offers a bill with remaining cash. The waiter grabs it. They usher Don to the door. The headwaiter retrieves Don’s hat, puts it on, and the bouncer drags him out, giving a final shove down the street. Don stops, leans on a railing, wipes his face, adjusts his hat, and glances back—doorman and taxi drivers watch him. Don straightens, walks home, burdened by shame. He passes waiting taxis under dim wall lights on the nightclub street. At home, the paper, milk, and Helen’s note remain untouched. Don climbs the steps, unlocks the door, and enters. He switches on the corridor light, stumbles to the couch, collapses, and hides his face. Later, wiping away tears, he notices something—on the ceiling, the bottle’s shadow from the light fixture. Smiling wildly, Don rises, laughing, moves the coffee table, stacks a chair, climbs up, and retrieves the bottle. He opens it fiercely. Don slowly opens his eyes, gets up, steadies himself on the bedpost and door frame, and exits the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Brevity - L2
test_cases.description: The attendant offers a towel, and Don wipes his hands. He notices Don's lapel, puzzled. Don tips him with fifty cents. The attendant chuckles and opens the bar door. Don leaves the washroom, walks slowly to his table, then stops, noticing everyone staring. Near the piano stand are the waiter, head waiter, pianist, and lovers. Suddenly, Don is the room's focus. M. M.'s escort grabs his coat. Don hands a bag to the lady, and the escort snatches it. Don offers a bill; the waiter takes it. They escort Don to the door. The headwaiter retrieves Don's hat, puts it on him, and the bouncer pushes him out. The bouncer shoves Don down the street. Don stops, leans on a railing, wipes his face, adjusts his hat, and heads home, burdened by shame. Taxis line the nightclub street. The newspaper, milk, and Helen's note remain. Don climbs steps, unlocks the door, leaves them untouched, enters, switches on the corridor light, and collapses on the couch. He wipes tears, sees a shadowed bottle, smiles crazily, and retrieves it. He opens the bottle. Don wakes, steadies on the bedpost, and exits the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L1
test_cases.description: The attendant, with a practiced and courteous gesture, extends a towel toward Don, who uses it to thoroughly wipe his hands clean. As Don does so, the attendant's gaze falls upon Don’s lapel, a look of puzzlement crossing his face. In response, Don offers the attendant a tip, a shiny fifty-cent piece, which the attendant accepts with a chuckle, though he doesn’t quite grasp the humor of the situation. Nevertheless, he laughs automatically and proceeds to open the door leading into the bar. Don exits the washroom and begins to walk slowly toward his table. Suddenly, he halts in his tracks and glances around the room. He realizes that all eyes are fixed on him. Near the small piano stand, Don notices his waiter, the head waiter, the piano player, and a pair of lovers, all staring intently. In fact, he becomes acutely aware that he is the center of attention for everyone present in the room. M. M.'s escort approaches him directly, grabbing him firmly by the coat. Don retrieves the bag from beneath his coat and hands it over to the lady. M. M.'s escort snatches it from his grasp. Don then holds out a bill and fishes out the remaining money from his pocket. The waiter quickly snatches it up. By this point, they have maneuvered Don to the door. The headwaiter retrieves Don’s hat from the checkroom girl, places it on Don’s head, and the bouncer pulls him through the door. The bouncer, dragging Don away from Harry's and Joe's, gives him one final shove down the street. Don comes to a halt and leans heavily against an iron railing, wiping his face with his hand. He adjusts his hat, glancing back. The doorman and the taxi drivers are watching him intently. Don turns away, straightens himself as best he can, and begins the journey home, the weight of shame pressing down on every limb. A line of waiting taxis stretches along the brilliantly illuminated nightclub street, which is meanly lit by the wall brackets. The newspaper, the bottle of milk, and Helen’s note remain exactly as they were. Don drags himself up the last few steps, unlocks the door, and enters, leaving the paper, bottle, and note untouched. Once inside, Don automatically switches on the light in the corridor. In a stupor of shame and misery, he stumbles over to the living room couch, flings himself down upon it, and lies there, covering his face with his arms. After some time, he brushes the tears from his eyes with his sleeve, and as he does so, he catches sight of something that rivets his attention and brings a half-crazed smile to his lips. On the ceiling is the shadow of the bottle he had hidden in the light fixture. With newfound strength, Don rises to his feet, nervous laughter shaking him. He pulls the coffee table under the light fixture, places a chair on it, climbs up, and retrieves his bottle. He climbs down again, opening the bottle with fierce determination. Don opens his eyes slowly. He gets up, steadying himself on the bedpost and holding the door frame, and he slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Verbosity - L2
test_cases.description: With a well-practiced and courteous gesture, the attendant extends a towel toward Don, who uses it diligently to thoroughly wipe his hands clean. As Don goes about this task, the attendant's gaze inadvertently falls upon Don’s lapel, a look of puzzlement momentarily crossing his face. In a reflexive response to the situation, Don offers the attendant a tip, a shiny fifty-cent piece, which the attendant receives with a chuckle, although he doesn’t entirely grasp the humor inherent in the situation. Nevertheless, he laughs automatically, and subsequently, he proceeds to open the door that leads into the bar. Don exits the washroom and begins to walk in a measured manner toward his table. Suddenly, he comes to a halt in his tracks and takes a moment to glance around the room. He comes to the realization that all eyes are intently fixed on him. Near the small piano stand, Don observes his waiter, the head waiter, the piano player, and a pair of lovers, all staring intently at him. In fact, he becomes acutely aware, with growing discomfort, that he is indeed the center of attention for everyone present in the room. At that moment, M. M.'s escort approaches him directly, grabbing him firmly by the coat. Don, maintaining his composure, retrieves the bag from beneath his coat and hands it over to the lady. M. M.'s escort snatches it swiftly from his grasp. Don then produces a bill and fishes out the remaining money from his pocket. The waiter quickly snatches it up without hesitation. By this point, they have maneuvered Don toward the door. The headwaiter retrieves Don’s hat from the checkroom girl, carefully places it on Don’s head, and the bouncer pulls him through the door with a firm grip. The bouncer, with determined force, drags Don away from Harry's and Joe's, eventually giving him one final shove down the dimly lit street. Don stumbles to a halt and leans heavily against an iron railing, wiping his face with the back of his hand. He adjusts his hat, casting a glance backward. The doorman and the taxi drivers stand watching him intently. Don turns away from their gaze, straightens himself as best he can manage, and begins the journey home, the weight of shame pressing down heavily on every limb. A line of waiting taxis stretches along the brilliantly illuminated nightclub street, which is meanly lit by the small wall brackets. The newspaper, the bottle of milk, and Helen’s note remain exactly as they were left. Don drags himself up the last few steps, unlocks the door, and enters, deliberately leaving the paper, bottle, and note untouched. Once inside, Don automatically switches on the light in the corridor. In a stupor filled with shame and misery, he stumbles over to the living room couch, flings himself down upon it, and lies there, covering his face with his arms in despair. After some time, he brushes the tears from his eyes with his sleeve. As he does so, he catches sight of something that rivets his attention and brings a half-crazed smile to his lips. On the ceiling is the ominous shadow of the bottle he had hidden in the light fixture. With newfound strength, Don rises to his feet, nervous laughter shaking him visibly. He pulls the coffee table under the light fixture, carefully places a chair on it, climbs up, and retrieves his hidden bottle. He climbs down again, opening the bottle with fierce determination. Later, Don opens his eyes slowly. He gets up, steadying himself by gripping the bedpost, holding the door frame, and he slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Macro-Actions -> Micro-Actions
test_cases.description: The attendant extends a towel toward Don, who takes it and methodically wipes his hands clean. As Don finishes, the attendant's gaze shifts to Don’s lapel, his expression one of confusion and curiosity. In response, Don reaches into his pocket and hands the attendant a fifty-cent piece as a tip. The attendant, not fully understanding the gesture, lets out a polite chuckle and proceeds to open the door leading into the bar. Don exits the washroom and begins to walk slowly toward his table, his pace deliberate and measured. Midway, he halts abruptly, his eyes scanning the room as he becomes acutely aware of the attention directed at him. Every person in the room, from the waiter and head waiter near the piano stand to the piano player and the couple engrossed in each other, has their eyes fixed on him. M. M.'s escort approaches Don with determination, grabbing him firmly by the coat. In response, Don reaches under his coat, retrieves a bag, and hands it over to the lady, only for M. M.'s escort to snatch it from his grasp. Don then extends a bill and rummages through his pocket for any remaining money, which the waiter quickly seizes. By this point, Don is being ushered toward the door. The headwaiter retrieves Don’s hat from the checkroom girl, places it on Don’s head, and the bouncer forcefully pulls him through the door. The bouncer continues to drag Don away from Harry's and Joe's, giving him a final shove that propels him down the street. Don eventually comes to a halt, leaning heavily against an iron railing, and wipes his face with his hand, trying to regain composure. He adjusts his hat, glances back, and notices the doorman and taxi drivers watching him intently. With a sense of resignation, Don turns away, straightens himself as much as he can, and begins the journey home, each step burdened by the weight of shame. The street is lined with waiting taxis, illuminated by the harsh light of wall brackets. Upon reaching his destination, Don finds the newspaper, the bottle of milk, and Helen’s note exactly as he left them. He drags himself up the last few steps, unlocks the door, and enters, leaving the paper, bottle, and note untouched. Once inside, Don instinctively switches on the corridor light. Overcome by a stupor of shame and misery, he stumbles into the living room, collapses onto the couch, and covers his face with his arms. After some time, he brushes away the tears with his sleeve and, in doing so, notices something that captures his attention and elicits a half-crazed smile. On the ceiling, he sees the shadow of the bottle he had hidden in the light fixture. This discovery invigorates him, and with newfound energy, Don rises to his feet, laughter tinged with nervousness escaping him. He moves the coffee table beneath the light fixture, places a chair on top, climbs up, and retrieves the hidden bottle. Descending carefully, he opens the bottle with a fierce determination. Later, Don slowly opens his eyes, and with effort, he gets up, using the bedpost for support. Holding onto the door frame for balance, he gradually makes his way out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Micro-Actions -> Macro-Actions
test_cases.description: The attendant offers a towel, which Don uses before tipping him with a fifty-cent piece. The attendant chuckles and opens the door to the bar. Don exits the washroom and heads toward his table, noticing that everyone, including the staff and patrons, is staring at him. M. M.'s escort approaches, grabs Don's coat, and takes a bag from him. Don hands over his remaining money to the waiter, who quickly takes it. The staff escorts Don to the door, where the headwaiter retrieves his hat, and the bouncer pushes him outside. The bouncer gives Don a final shove down the street, where he stops to lean against a railing, wipes his face, and adjusts his hat. Observed by the doorman and taxi drivers, Don turns and heads home, burdened by shame. Ignoring the newspaper, milk, and note at his door, he enters his apartment, switches on the light, and collapses on the couch, overwhelmed by shame and misery. After wiping his tears, he notices the shadow of a hidden bottle on the ceiling, which brings a smile to his face. Gaining new resolve, Don retrieves the bottle from the light fixture, opens it, and drinks. Later, he awakens, steadies himself, and slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Insert Attributes, Emotions and Scene
test_cases.description: The attendant holds out a towel, and Don wipes his hands. He looks at Don’s lapel, mystified by the unusual emblem of a secretive club known for its discreet dealings. Don tips the attendant with a fifty-cent piece, a significant amount in a time when the average daily wage was only a few dollars. The attendant doesn’t get the joke about the generosity but chuckles automatically and opens the door into the bar, an elegant establishment known locally for its jazz nights and famous clientele. Don walks from the washroom, slowly toward his table. Suddenly he stops and looks around. They are staring at Don. Near the little piano stand—a vintage instrument played by many renowned musicians in its day—stand Don’s waiter, the head waiter, the piano player, and the lovers. In fact, he’s suddenly aware that he is the focus of every eye in the room. M. M.'s escort, a brawny man reputed to deal with troublemakers swiftly, is right at him, grabbing him by the coat. He takes the bag out from under his coat and hands it to the lady, a renowned socialite known for her frequent appearances in the society pages. M. M.'s escort snatches it from his hand. Don holds out the bill, crisp and slightly crumpled from anxiety, and fishes what money he has left from his pocket. The waiter snaps it up, an unspoken rule in places like these ensuring money moves fast. By this time, they’ve got Don to the door. The headwaiter gets Don’s hat from the checkroom girl’s hand, a hat that had been a stylish purchase from a popular boutique, puts it on Don’s head, and the bouncer pulls him through the door. The bouncer, dragging Don from Harry's and Joe's, a well-known speakeasy hidden beneath the guise of a legal bar, gives him one last shove down the street. Don comes to a stop and leans heavily against an iron railing, part of the ornate exterior of the building, wiping his face with his hand. He straightens his hat, looks back. The doorman, who has seen it all, and the taxi drivers, familiar figures in this nocturnal world, are staring after him. Don turns, straightens himself as best he can, and starts for home, shame weighing down every limb. There is a line of waiting taxis along the brilliantly lighted nightclub street, known for its vibrant nightlife and occasional scandals. It is meanly lighted by the wall brackets, casting harsh shadows that echo the mood. The newspaper, the bottle of milk, and Helen’s note are all as they were, remnants of normalcy left abandoned. Don drags himself up the last few steps, unlocks the door, and goes in, leaving the paper, bottle, and note untouched, signifying a detachment from reality. Don has entered. Automatically he switches on the light in the corridor, the dim bulb flickering slightly. In a stupor of shame and misery, he stumbles over to the living room couch, flings himself down on it, and lies covering his face with his arms. After a time, he brushes the tears from his eyes with his sleeve and, as he does so, catches sight of something which rivets his attention and brings a half-crazed smile to his lips. On the ceiling is the shadow of the bottle which he hid in the light fixture, a clandestine cache for his troubled moments. With new strength, Don gets to his feet, nervous laughter shaking him. He pulls the coffee table under the light fixture, puts the chair on it, climbs up, and retrieves his bottle, a familiar and temporary escape from his troubles. He climbs down again, opening the bottle fiercely, its contents offering forgetfulness. Don opens his eyes slowly, the morning light harsh and accusatory. Don gets up, steadying himself on the bedpost, a relic from better days, and holding the door frame, he slowly moves out of the bedroom, the weight of last night's escapade lingering.

Amidst the roaring tempest of a stormy ocean a weathered sailor battles nature’s fury on a creaking vessel his resolve as steadfast as the crashing waves that threaten to engulf him. On a bustling 1960s New York street a passionate artist finds unexpected inspiration in the chaotic interplay of urban life capturing moments of love loss and defiant hope on a rainsoaked canvas. Deep in the heart of an enchanted forest a brave knight embarks on a perilous quest to rescue a captive princess facing mythical creatures and treacherous traps with unwavering courage. During a heated political rally in a futuristic city a charismatic leader stokes both hope and dissent. as holographic banners illuminate the night sky and fervent crowds surge with anticipation. In the eerie silence of a postapocalyptic wasteland a hardened survivor scavenges through abandoned ruins haunted by the echoes of a oncethriving civilization now reduced to dust. Beneath the shimmering surface of an underwater kingdom a rebellious mermaid defies ancient traditions to explore forbidden coral reefs and secret caverns brimming with forgotten lore. In the quiet confines of a suburban attic an unassuming teenager stumbles upon a mysterious portal that thrusts him into a surreal world where the very fabric of time and space unravels. On the rugged highlands of Scotland a stoic warrior faces rival clans and ancient curses alike his fierce battle cry resonating across mistcovered moors and turbulent skies. Amid the vibrant chaos of a South American carnival a fearless dancer twirls through streets bursting with color and rhythm each graceful move challenging the rigid boundaries of tradition. During a clandestine meeting in a snowcovered mountain lodge two rival spies exchange cryptic messages hinting at an imminent global conspiracy. their whispered words carried off by the howling wind. Inside a lavish 1920s speakeasy a troubled jazz musician pours his soul into a melancholic melody every note echoing the bittersweet memories of lost love and shattered dreams. In a futuristic space station orbiting a distant planet an intrepid crew confronts bizarre alien phenomena and an enigmatic interstellar threat pushing the limits of human endurance. Amidst the chaos of a raging civil war a compassionate medic races through bombedout streets. his every desperate step a race against time to save lives in the midst of utter devastation. On a sundappled afternoon in a quaint European village an eccentric inventor unveils a groundbreaking contraption that defies conventional physics igniting wonder and skepticism in equal measure. In a bustling marketplace in ancient Persia a cunning street thief navigates labyrinthine alleyways and vibrant bazaars. his calculated every move a daring escape from the everwatchful royal guards. In the neonlit back alleys of a dystopian metropolis a rogue hacker races against time while being chased by relentless cyborg enforcers their footsteps echoing off rainsoaked pavement. Under the relentless desert sun a lone gunslinger confronts a notorious outlaw at a deserted crossroads both men exchanging steely glances as swirling dust blurs the horizon. On a foggy evening in Victorian London an intrepid detective uncovers a hidden conspiracy among the city’s elite with gaslit streets setting the stage for a race against a mounting darkness. High above a sprawling city skyline a daredevil pilot executes deathdefying maneuvers in a vintage biplane narrowly evading enemy fire as the ground morphs into a dizzying mosaic below. Within the creaking walls of an old countryside manor an estranged family gathers for a mysterious inheritance their hushed whispers and secret glances weaving a tapestry of betrayal and suspense. He straightens his hat looks back. The doorman and the taxi drivers are staring after him. Don turns straightens himself as best he can and starts for home shame weighing down every limb. There is a line of waiting taxis along the brilliantly lighted nightclub street. It is meanly lighted by the wall brackets. The newspaper the bottle of milk and Helen’s note are all as they were. Don drags himself up the last few steps unlocks the door and goes in leaving the paper bottle and note untouched. Don has entered. Automatically he switches on the light in the corridor. In a stupor of shame and misery he stumbles over to the living room couch flings himself down on it and lies covering his face with his arms. After a time he brushes the tears from his eyes with his sleeve and as he does so catches sight of something which rivets his attention and brings a halfcrazed smile to his lips. On the ceiling is the shadow of the bottle which he hid in the light fixture. With new strength Don gets to his feet nervous laughter shaking him. He pulls the coffee table under the light fixture puts the chair on it climbs up and retrieves his bottle. He climbs down again opening the bottle fiercely. Don opens his eyes slowly. Don gets up. steadying himself on the bedpost and holding the door frame. he slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Deletion (~50%)
test_cases.description: The attendant holds out a towel and Don wipes his hands. He looks at Don’s lapel. mystified Don tips the attendant with a fiftycent piece. The attendant does not get the joke but chuckles automatically and opens the door into the bar. Don walks from the washroom slowly toward his table. Suddenly he stops and looks around. They are staring at Don. Near the little piano stand Don’s waiter the head waiter the piano player and the lovers. In fact he is suddenly aware that he is the focus of every eye in the room. In a stupor of shame and misery he stumbles over to the living room couch flings himself down on it and lies covering his face with his arms. After a time he brushes the tears from his eyes with his sleeve and as he does so catches sight of something which rivets his attention and brings a halfcrazed smile to his lips. On the ceiling is the shadow of the bottle which he hid in the light fixture. With new strength Don gets to his feet nervous laughter shaking him. He pulls the coffee table under the light fixture puts the chair on it climbs up and retrieves his bottle. He climbs down again opening the bottle fiercely. Don opens his eyes slowly. Don gets up. steadying himself on the bedpost and holding the door frame. he slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.description: The attendant holds out a towel and Don wipes his hands. He looks at Don’s lapel. mystified Don tips the attendant with a fiftycent piece. The attendant does not get the joke but chuckles automatically and opens the door into the bar. Don opens his eyes slowly. Don gets up. steadying himself on the bedpost and holding the door frame. he slowly moves out of the bedroom.

test_cases.name: Subject-Action-Object Corruption
test_cases.description: The sailor extends a scarf, and Bob cleans his elbows. He glances at Bob’s buckle, puzzled. Bob bribes the sailor with a ten-cent stamp. The sailor doesn’t understand the riddle but giggles politely and shuts the window into the lounge. Bob drifts from the ballroom, quickly toward his booth. Suddenly he pauses and glances around. They are glaring at Bob. Beside the tiny drum kit Bob’s chef, the head chef, the drummer, and the poets. Indeed, he’s abruptly conscious that he is the target of every gaze in the hall. M. M.'s guardian is right at him, clutching him by the collar. He extracts the balloon out from under his collar and presents it to the gentleman. M. M.'s guardian grabs it from his grip. Bob offers the coin and retrieves what candy he has left from his satchel. The chef swipes it away. By this moment, they’ve pushed Bob to the gate. The head chef takes Bob’s scarf from the laundry girl’s basket, places it on Bob’s shoulders, and the gardener shoves him through the tunnel. The gardener, towing Bob from Lucy's and Sam's, gives him one final push down the trail. Bob halts and slumps heavily against a wooden fence, scrubbing his feet with his toe. He adjusts his scarf, peers back. The blacksmith and the bus drivers are glaring after him. Bob pivots, corrects himself as best he can, and heads for the park, agony burdening every muscle. There is a queue of waiting buses along the dimly glowing library path. It is dimly lit by the tree lanterns. The magazine, the carton of juice, and Linda’s postcard are all as they were. Bob hauls himself up the final few rungs, unseals the gate, and enters, leaving the magazine, carton, and postcard unexamined. Bob has arrived. Unthinkingly he flips on the lamp in the hallway. In a daze of guilt and despair, he staggers to the dining room armchair, tosses himself down on it, and lies covering his mouth with his hands. After a while, he wipes the sweat from his forehead with his jacket and, as he does so, notices something which seizes his focus and brings a half-dazed grin to his eyebrows. On the curtain is the outline of the carton which he buried in the chandelier. With renewed vigor, Bob jumps to his knees, hysterical chuckling shaking him. He tugs the dining table beneath the chandelier, places the ladder on it, climbs up, and reclaims his carton. He steps down again, unsealing the carton hungrily. Bob opens his fingers slowly. Bob rises, bracing himself on the nightstand and clutching the window frame, he swiftly glides out of the studio.

test_cases.name: Complete Corruption
test_cases.description: The film starts with a man waking up in a small apartment. He prepares coffee and checks his phone for messages. There are none, so he heads out to catch a bus. On the way, he passes a neighbor who greets him briefly. At the bus stop, he notices a group of students talking about an upcoming test. He boards the bus and sits near the back, watching the city pass by outside the window. After a few stops, he gets off near a large office building. He enters the lobby and goes through security. He rides an elevator to the tenth floor, where he works as an assistant. His manager asks him to prepare some documents for a meeting later in the day. He collects files from different departments and organizes them in a conference room. Another employee asks him for help with a software issue, so he takes a few minutes to fix it. Then he returns to the conference room to double-check everything before the meeting begins. The meeting starts at noon. Several people join via video call, and others sit around the table. The manager outlines the project goals, and each team member shares updates on their tasks. There are questions about deadlines and budgets, but no big surprises. After an hour, they end the call. The manager thanks everyone and leaves. The assistant cleans up the room, collects leftover notes, and heads back to his desk. During lunch, he walks to a nearby café, where he orders a simple meal. He eats alone and checks social media on his phone. After lunch, he returns to the office and finishes smaller tasks, such as sending emails and filing paperwork. He also helps a coworker carry boxes of supplies to another floor. Later in the afternoon, the manager calls him in to discuss next week's schedule. They go over a few changes, and the assistant updates the calendar. When the workday ends, he logs off his computer and leaves the building. Outside, he walks a few blocks to meet a friend. They chat about weekend plans and decide to see a film on Saturday. The assistant then heads home on a crowded bus. At his apartment, he sorts his mail, feeds a pet cat, and warms up leftovers for dinner. He watches a short news segment on TV, then checks his phone again. A message from his friend confirms their plan for the weekend. He feels relieved to have something to look forward to. The film ends with him preparing for bed, setting an alarm, and turning off the lights. He reflects briefly on the day, thinking about his tasks, his quiet home, and the plans ahead.

test_cases.name: Summarization
test_cases.description: The attendant offers Don a towel, which he uses to wipe his hands. Don, perplexed by a detail on his lapel, tips the attendant, who opens the door to the bar. As Don walks to his table, he realizes everyone, including the waitstaff and patrons, is watching him. M. M.'s escort confronts Don, grabbing him by the coat and taking a bag he hands over. Don pays the waiter, and the headwaiter retrieves Don's hat as the bouncer pushes him out the door. Shoved down the street, Don stops against a railing, adjusts his hat, and returns home feeling ashamed. Ignoring the newspaper, milk, and note, he enters, turns on the light, and collapses on the couch in despair. Eventually, he notices the shadow of a hidden bottle on the ceiling, smiles, and retrieves it. With nervous laughter, he climbs down, opens the bottle, and drinks. Later, Don wakes, steadies himself, and slowly exits the bedroom.
